page.title: 16SMEATHARPE - RURAL POVERTY
page.content: As there is no industry in rural areas there is no competition for labour. Thus those working in the country, be it in agriculture etc. are generally poorly paid. There is no local housing in this area or privately rented accomodation. If a lowly paid worker has to leave his home, e.g. tied house, often he cannot afford to buy a house locally. Another burden on low-paid people living in the country is the necessity of owning a car, of whatever vintage. To-day the Road Fund Tax is Â£1OO per year, as is the average insurance. Petrol is around Â£2 per gallon (4.5 litres). Repair costs in a garage are high as is depreciation in the selling price of the vehicle.
